text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This revised IRM incorporates the Program Scope and Objectives subsection as required by IRM 1.11.2, Internal Management Documents System, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process.
IRM 6.531.1.3.3 (2) removed procedural content for requesting a special rate and included a link to OPM’s Form 1397, Special Salary Request Form.
6.530.1.3.6 (2) removed reference to non-foreign area cost-of-living adjustments and post
This IRM supersedes IRM 6.530.1, Aggregate Limitations on Pay and Special Rate Schedules, dated January 26, 2010.

) Purpose: This IRM covers administration of aggregate limitation on pay Senior Executive Services (SES) and General Schedule (GS) positions special rate schedules for the GS and GL (Law Enforcement Officers positions. This IRM also applies to employees in other pay plans (e.g., Payband System (IR)) moving into GS or GL positions. (

) Audience: Unless otherwise indicated, the policies, authorities, and instructions contained in this IRM apply to all business units. Unit (BU) employees should review negotiated agreement provisions subjects in this IRM. Should any of these instructions conﬂict with a of a negotiated agreement, the agreement will prevail. (
) Policy Owner: The IRS Human Capital Officer. (
) Program Owner: The Human Capital Office (HCO), Office of HR (OHRS), Policy and Compliance (P&C). (
) Primary Stakeholders: All business units responsible for the aggregate limitation on pay and special rate schedules for employees. (
) Program Goals: This IRM provides guidance, awareness, and on aggregate limitation on pay and special rate schedules to stakeholders. (

) Unless otherwise indicated, the policies, authorities, and instructions out this IRM apply to all IRS business units. This guidance must be read interpreted in accordance with pertinent law (United States Code ernmentwide regulation (Code of Federal Regulations (CFR)), the Capital Issuance System (HCIS) Directives, and Comptroller General OPM decisions, as applicable. Limitation on Pay and Special Rate 6.530.1
Primary Stakeholders: All business units responsible for the administration of aggregate limitation on pay and special rate schedules for employees.
Program Goals: This IRM provides guidance, awareness, and understanding on aggregate limitation on pay and special rate schedules to organizations and
Aggregate Limitations on Pay and Special Schedules • Subpart B - Aggregate Limitation on Pay; and • Subpart C - Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention. c. Part
- Pay Under the General Schedule; d. Part
- Grade and Pay Retention; and e. Part
- Pay Administration Under the Fair Labor Standards Act. (

) The IRS Human Capital Officer is the executive responsible for this IRM overall Servicewide policy for aggregate limitation on pay and special rate schedules. (
) The P&C organization is responsible for updating, maintaining, and this IRM. (

) The HCO, Office of HR Operations (OHRO), HR Shared Services (HRSS) ganization is responsible for maintaining records to facilitate the of the aggregate limitation on pay. The IRS must provide records to the employer when an employee covered by this limitation transfers to another bureau or agency. (

) This IRM provides policy guidance on aggregate limitation on pay and rate schedules. The P&C organization gauges the effectiveness of this based on feedback from customers and staff members about subjects contained in this IRM. During the review and publishing of this IRM, are added or deleted based on statutory and/or regulatory changes and in part on this process. (

) The P&C organization develops and deploys policies, materials and to increase Servicewide awareness and understanding of the aggregate tion on pay and special rate schedules. Additionally, P&C collaborates with other HCO organizations and Servicewide stakeholders to support and outreach activities as they relate to aggregate limitation on pay and special rate schedules. (

) The following activities help ensure program success: a. Conducting annual policy reviews; b. Publishing educational articles, such as Leaders’ Alerts and IRS Headlines; and c. Maintaining accurate and up-to-date program websites.
6.530 Aggregate Limitations on Pay and Special Schedules
Subpart B - Aggregate Limitation on Pay; and Subpart C - Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and
Limitation on Pay and Special Rate 6.530.1
Find a complete list of deﬁnitions regarding aggregate limitation on pay and special rate schedules at 5 CFR 530.202 and 530.302.

Premium pay; Incentive awards and performance-based cash awards; Recruitment, relocation, and retention incentives; Extended assignment incentives; Supervisory differentials; Post differentials; Danger pay allowances; Post differentials based on environmental conditions for employees stationed in non-foreign areas; Physicians’ comparability allowances under
USC
; Continuation of pay; Lump-sum payments in excess of the aggregate limitation on pay, as required by
CFR
, Payment of excess amounts; and Other similar payments authorized under
USC, excluding

Overtime pay under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) of 1938, as amended, severance pay, lump-sum payments for accumulated and accrued annual leave upon separation, back pay awarded to an employee because of an unjustiﬁed personnel action, student loan repayments under 5 USC 5379, and non-foreign area cost-of-living allowances.
b. Aggregate Limitation: the limitation on aggregate compensation received in any given calendar year (CY), as established by
USC

, Limitation on certain payments. c. Basic Pay: the total amount of pay received at a rate ﬁxed by law or ad- ministrative action for the position held by an employee, including any special rate under
CFR Part
, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention, or any locality-based comparability payment under
CFR Part

, Subpart F, Locality-Based Comparability Payments, or other similar payment under other legal authority, before any deductions. Basic pay includes night and environmental differentials for prevailing rate employees under
USC
(f), Prevailing rate deter- minations; wage schedules; night differentials, and
CFR

, Environmental differentials. Basic pay excludes additional pay of any other kind. d. Discretionary Payment: a payment an agency has discretion to make to an employee. e. Estimated Aggregate Compensation: the agency’s projection of the aggregate compensation an employee would receive during a CY, but for application of the aggregate limitation to future payments. This projection must be based on known factors. Estimated aggregate compensation includes:
The total amount of basic pay the employee will receive during the CY; Any lump-sum payment of excess amounts from a previous CY, as described in
CFR
, Payment of excess amounts;
Aggregate Limitations on Pay and Special Rate Schedules
Schedules
The total amount of non-discretionary payments the employee would be entitled to receive during the CY; and

The total amount of discretionary payments the employee would be au- thorized to receive during the CY. f. Law Enforcement Officer (LEO) Special Base Rate: a special base established for GS LEOs at grades GS
through GS
under section
of the Federal Employees Pay Comparability Act of
, which is used in lieu of a GS rate. g. Special Rate: a rate of pay within a special rate schedule established under
CFR
, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention. h. Special Rate Schedule: a pay schedule established under
CFR

, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention, to provide higher rates of pay for speciﬁed categories of GS positions or employees at one or more grades. An increased or decreased special rate schedule refers to an increase or decrease in one or more rate ranges within that schedule. i. Special Rate Supplement: the portion of a special rate paid above an employee’s GS rate. However, for a LEO receiving a LEO special base rate, who is also entitled to a special rate, the special rate supplement equals the portion of the special rate paid above the officer’s LEO base rate. When a special rate schedule covers both LEO positions and other positions, the value of the special rate supplement will be less for LEOs receiving a LEO special base rate (since that rate is higher than corresponding GS rate). The payable amount of a special rate is subject to the Executive Schedule Level IV limitation on special rates, as provided in
CFR
(a), Establishing or increasing special (

) This IRM establishes policy for limiting an employee’s aggregate annual com- pensation. CFR Part Subpart D, Performance Appraisal Certiﬁcation for Pay Purposes, of the mance appraisal system covering the employee. These regulations must be applied in conjunction with
USC

through GS

of the Federal Employees Pay Comparability Act of

, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention. h. Special Rate Schedule: a pay schedule established under
CFR

, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention, to provide higher rates of pay for speciﬁed categories of GS positions or employees at one or more grades. An increased or decreased special rate schedule refers to an increase or decrease in one or more rate ranges within that schedule. i. Special Rate Supplement: the portion of a special rate paid above an employee’s GS rate. However, for a LEO receiving a LEO special base rate, who is also entitled to a special rate, the special rate supplement equals the portion of the special rate paid above the officer’s LEO special base rate. When a special rate schedule covers both LEO positions and other positions, the value of the special rate supplement will be less for LEOs receiving a LEO special base rate (since that rate is higher than corresponding GS rate). The payable amount of a special rate is subject to the Executive Schedule Level IV limitation on special rates, as provided in
CFR
(a), Establishing or increasing special rates.

) The
USC, Chapter

, Personnel Flexibilities Relating to the Internal Revenue Service, sets forth certain personnel ﬂexibilities relating to the and enabling the Secretary of the Treasury to take the following actions: a. Under
(a), Pay authority for critical positions, request that OPM authorize critical pay for one or more IRS position(s) to be paid at any rate up to the salary of the Vice President (
USC
, Salary of the President); b. Under
(a), Streamlined critical pay authority, no later than September
as amended by the Taxpayer First Act of

, the pay of an executive under the Streamlined Critical Pay Authority positions critical to the functionality of the Information Technology (IT) operations of the IRS. to be paid at any rate up to the salary of the President (
USC
, Salary of the Vice President); and c. Under
(e), Performance awards for senior executives, no later September
as amended by the Taxpayer First Act of

, a performance bonus award to a member of the SES, who has management responsibilities over IT operations, to the extent that the executive’s total annual compensation does not exceed the total compensation payable to the Vice President (
USC
, Salary of Vice President). (
) The aggregate compensation of an employee receiving any payment under USC
, Pay authority for critical positions,
, Streamlined critical authority, and
, Performance awards for senior executives, may not exceed the total annual compensation payable to the Vice President in dance with
USC
, Salary of the Vice President. (
) Amounts in excess of limitations described above must be paid to the employee in a lump-sum payment at the beginning of the following CY as provided at
CFR
, Payment of excess amounts. This lump sum payment is considered a part of the employee’s aggregate compensation the new CY. (

) If, in a new CY, any lump-sum payment causes an employee’s estimated aggregate compensation to exceed the applicable aggregate limitation for current CY, the IRS must consider only the employee’s rate of basic pay (includes locality based payment under
CFR Part
Subpart F, Locality- Based Comparability Payments, as well as any special rate under
CFR

, Pay Rates and Systems (General)) expected to be paid to determine extent of the lump-sum payment that may be paid. An agency must defer other payments in order to pay as much of the lump-sum amount as Any deferred payments (including any portion of the lump-sum payment excess amount that was not payable) are payable at the beginning of the CY. ) In the IRS, special rates may apply to GS and GL positions. (
) As provided in
CFR

, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for and Retention, this section contains rules for determining an employee’s of pay when a special rate schedule is established, increased, decreased, discontinued, or when conditions for coverage under a special rate are changed. (
) For pay-setting rules, refer to IRM
, Pay Under the General and IRS Payband System, at IRM
aspx, and for grade and pay retention rules refer to IRM Grade/Band and Pay Retention, at http://irm.web.irs.gov/Part

/ Section

aspx. (
) Special rate schedules under
USC
, Special pay authority, do not to IRS Payband System employees. (

) An employee’s coverage under a special rate schedule is subject to established by OPM and may be based on occupation, grade, employing agency, geographic location, or other factors determined by OPM. (

) The IRS must pay the applicable special rate to any employee who meets coverage criteria established by OPM. The Commissioner of Internal can request an exception from the Department of the Treasury (Treasury) exclude a category of employees within the IRS from coverage under a proposed or existing special rate schedule. (

) An employee covered by a special rate schedule is not paid a special rate they are entitled to a higher rate of basic pay under any other legal For example, an employee is not entitled to a special rate if they are a higher locality rate or a retained rate. (
) The OPM considers the circumstances and factors listed at
CFR Establishing or increasing special rates, and
, Evaluating agency requests for new or increased special rates, when evaluating the need for Rates special rates. (
) The OPM may increase the minimum rates of basic pay to a category of employees to address signiﬁcant recruitment or retention difficulties. (
) A minimum special rate may not exceed
% of the maximum underlying for the grade, and the maximum rate may not exceed Level IV of the Schedule.

-day break in service. If an individual is reemployed in the federal service within the same CY, the lump-sum payment is included in the aggregate compensation for the year.

, Agency for requests for new or increased special rates. Business units should contact P&C regarding the initiation of such requests. (

, at https://www.opm.gov/ policy-data-oversight/pay-leave/pay-systems/special-rates-requests/opm
pdf. (
) A completed Worksheet for Special Rate Requests, Form

, must be approved by the business unit head of office, or equivalent, to authorize the request and funding while certifying that the requested special rates are sidered necessary to ensure staffing adequate to the accomplishment of the IRS mission. The request is then forwarded to the IRS Human Capital for concurrence and submission to Treasury. (

CFR
, Evaluating agency requests for new or increased special rates. or Rates (

) The OPM may review an established special rate schedule at any time. Typically, the OPM requests information from agencies on an annual basis they review special rate schedules. The OPM will request information for the review directly or designate a lead agency. (

) When annual GS pay adjustments are applied, the OPM also determines whether they will apply the same annual adjustment to special rates, and if special rate should be increased, decreased, or discontinued. (

(01-26-2010) Treatment of Special Rate as Rate of Basic Pay
Aggregate Limitations on Pay and Special Schedules (
) See
CFR
(c), Treatment of special rate as basic pay, when setting pay for employees moving from special rate positions to prevailing rate positions. (

) Special rates may apply to an entire special rate schedule or to a portion of the schedule. When a locality rate exceeds a special rate schedule or a of that schedule, the special rate is terminated. Positions may have a rate and a locality rate as the highest applicable rate range. This is referred to as a hybrid schedule or range (e.g., GS
, step
to step
by special rate and GS
, step
and above covered by locality rate). (
) A special rate may be paid only for those hours for which an employee is in pay status. (
) A pay increase caused by an employee becoming entitled to a new or special rate supplement is not considered an equivalent increase in pay (
CFR
(c), Equivalent increase determinations). (
) A special rate is included in an employee’s total remuneration, as deﬁned in CFR
(b), Hourly regular rate of pay, and straight time rate of pay, as deﬁned in
CFR
(b), Overtime pay entitlement, for the purpose of overtime pay computations under the FLSA. (
) The reduction or termination of an employee’s special rate supplement, in cordance with the requirements of
CFR Part
, Subpart C, Special Rate Schedules for Recruitment and Retention (which includes a change in where a lower or no special rate exists), is not an adverse action under
Part
, Subpart D, Regulatory Requirements for Removal, Suspension for More Than
Days, Reduction in Grade or Pay, or Furlough for
Days or Less. (

6.530 Aggregate Limitations on Pay and Special Schedules
See 5 CFR 530.308(c), Treatment of special rate as basic pay, when setting pay for employees moving from special rate positions to prevailing rate
These rules are considered general pay adjustments for the purpose of dealing with the order of precedence for processing simultaneous pay actions.
When a special rate schedule for a position is discontinued or decreased, pay
Limitation on Pay and Special Rate 6.530.1

a. If the employee’s rate of basic pay is equal to one of the steps in the highest applicable rate range (including locality or special rate supple- ment), pay is set at that step. b. If the employee’s rate of basic pay is between two steps in the highest applicable rate range, pay is set at the higher of the two steps. c. If the employee’s rate of basic pay exceeds the maximum rate of the highest applicable rate range, pay remains at its current rate, and the employee is entitled to pay retention in accordance with

CFR Mandatory pay retention. If an employee changes to a worksite with no special rate or a lower special rate, pay retention will not apply. A reduction in an employee’s payable rate basic pay resulting from this geographic conversion is not a basis for entitle-

If an employee changes to a worksite with no special rate or a lower special rate, pay retention will not apply. A reduction in an employee’s payable rate of basic pay resulting from this geographic conversion is not a basis for entitle- ment to pay retention (
CFR
(a), Geographic conversion).

If an employee changes to a worksite with no special rate or a lower special rate, pay retention will not apply. A reduction in an employee’s payable rate of basic pay resulting from this geographic conversion is not a basis for entitle- ment to pay retention (5 CFR 536.303(a), Geographic conversion).
